sub_title: Assistant Professor at Leiden University College
summary:
I am an Assistant Professor at Leiden University College (LUC) in the Hague, where I lead the interdisciplinary laboratory Decision Engineering for SustaInability and REsilience (DESIRE).

I am also Co-Chair of the Weighting Subtask of the Life Cycle Initiative, hosted by the United Nations Environment Programme. The Life Cycle Initiative is a public-private, multi-stakeholder partnership enabling the global use of credible life cycle knowledge by private and public decision makers.

Expertise: 
• Development of Decision Support Systems with Multiple Criteria Decision Aiding/Analysis (MCDA). 
• Main frameworks: sustainability, resilience and risk assessment. 
• Main application areas: materials and processes development, chemical safety, energy systems, technologies assessment.

My website: https://sites.google.com/view/marcocinelli

profile_positions.description:
I am an Assistant Professor at Leiden University College (LUC) in the Hague, where I lead the interdisciplinary laboratory Decision Engineering for SustaInability and REsilience (DESIRE).

I am also Co-Chair of the Weighting Subtask of the Life Cycle Initiative, hosted by the United Nations Environment Programme. The Life Cycle Initiative is a public-private, multi-stakeholder partnership enabling the global use of credible life cycle knowledge by private and public decision makers.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: Co-chairing the Weighting Subtask of the project "Global Guidance for Life Cycle Impact Assessment Indicators and Methods (GLAM)". This is part of the Life Cycle Initiative, hosted by the United Nations Environment Programme. The Life Cycle Initiative is a public-private, multi-stakeholder partnership enabling the global use of credible life cycle knowledge by private and public decision makers.
profile_positions.title: Co-Chair

profile_positions.description:
2nd part of three-year Global Fellowship under the EU Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions scheme. The project, “Sustainability Assessment based on Decision Aiding (SAbDA)”, is focused on:

➢ Multiple Criteria-based materials and technologies assessment, with a specific focus on land remediation technologies, energy systems analysis and safety of chemicals from a life-cycle perspective  

➢ Expansion of a network of researchers, analysts and policy makers to advance the scientifically meaningful use of MCDA in sustainability, resilience and risk research

Advisors: Prof. Roman Słowiński; Dr. Peter Burgherr; Dr. Michael Gonzalez; Asst. Prof. Miłosz Kadziński

Outgoing phase for US EPA and Paul Scherrer Institute; Incoming phase at the Institute of Computing Science, Poznan University of Technology
profile_positions.title: Marie Curie Global Research Fellow

profile_positions.description:
➢ Development of metrics and decision support tools for the resilience assessment of energy systems

➢ Development of classification models for risk assessment of energy accidents

➢ Development of sustainability, resilience and risk assessment capabilities within the Future Resilient Systems (FRS) Programme of Singapore-ETH Centre

Advisors: Dr. Peter Burgherr, Dr. Matteo Spada
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
➢ Development of a weighting scheme for life cycle impact assessment categories in the Environmental Product Footprint methodology, based on MCDA

➢ Creation of a research agenda of key challenges to be tackled to maximize the practical use of life cycle assessment in the context of European Commission’s Better Regulation package
profile_positions.title: Visiting Scientist

company.name: Institute of Advanced Study, University of Warwick

profile_positions.description:
➢ Use of Multiple Criteria Decision Aiding (MCDA) to perform sustainability assessments of products/process systems (in collaboration with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the Institute of Computing Science in Poland)

➢ Creation of a network of sustainability and decision support analysts to advance the scientifically meaningful use of MCDA in sustainability research
